body.p:
I am becoming a frequent correspondt.
and may possibly weary you with my scribble. However
the present communication is for your services in aid of
our proposed Sunday School which will come into operation
on Sunday next the 27th Inst.

The Ladies have commissioned me to
request you will forward by first opportunity the following
Books.

list.item: 2 dz Old Testament Bibles, no headings.

A few sets of the American Jewish Library, particularly
the Epitome of the Bible, by Cunery.

1 dz Matineé's de Samedi, translated by Abrahams
of Liverpool

body.p:
together with a small selection of any works used generally by
the Philadelphia Sunday School, and a couple of copies of
their Bye Laws, as also of the Sewing Society, and the full do.
Please forward the Bill at same times. It would perhaps
be as well to send the whole by steamer from New York.
You may also pack up ½ dz Eu Miss Aguilar's Women of
Israel, Jewish Faith, and her other works which you edited,
these 3 latter on my acct.

Now for a few particulars for the Occident.
On Sunday the 6th Inst. the ladies worshipping at the Synagogue
Dispersed of Judah, held their first meeting at my house, Mrs.
B. Florance in the chair. Sundry Resolutions were passed
to be confirmed at the next meeting on Sunday the 13th. On
this occasion 22 ladies offered themselves as teachers, and elected
Mrs. B. Florance Superintendant, Mrs. M. N. Nathan Treasurer,
Secy. Mrs Nathan declining to accept any office, Mrs.
?cted in her stead. A Resolution passed requesting

body.p:
the ladies, officers and teachers to collect subscriptions. Sunday
the 20th the ladies had their 3rd meeting at my house, when
the sum of $334.20 was handed in as collections. The School
will be opened the 27th. I have drawn up a code of Bye
Laws, and officiated as Secretary; but you must not mention
it, as I wish the petticoats to have all the credit. You can
merely say, I gave them my advice and assistance in organizing
the School. I have every reason to believe the school will
be very successful. The youth of both sexes belonging to the
two congregations in the city, and that of Lafayette are
united to attend as pupils; but the government of the School
will be managed by the ladies worshipping at the Portuguese
Synagogue, who are now or may hereafter become teachers.

I wish to be informed respecting a female who
came here some weeks ago, a widow, calling herself Mrs. Rice
who says she has long resided in your city, where her husband
kept a large Jeweller's shop. Her uncle, according to her acct
resides there now, his name is Brühl. Her story is to this effect.
A sister named Fernbein living at Cincinnati wrote for her
and on arriving at that city, she found her sister had removed
to N. O. No such persons, after due inquiry, could be found
here; and she applied for assistance to go back to Pa
to her uncle. From many circumstances, people here think
she is somewhat of an impostor. I am half inclined to that
opinion myself. However some money was made up for her
to enable her to return via Cincinnati. She quitted yesterday.
She told us her child was poisoned some years ago by her
servant girl. The impression she made has been any thing but
favourable even upon those who espoused her cause.

All your friends whose name is Legion send
their regards, and hoping your health is
improving, and with best wishes in which
Mrs. N. joins I am Truly yours
